bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The newly adopted By-Laws of 1953 provided for an elected Vice-President who was a member of the Board of Trustees. Thomas Milton Rivers was elected the first Vice-President of the newly constituted Board of Trustees and served as Director of The Institute, Director of the Department of Laboratories and Director of the Hospital until his retirement in 1955.

August 1955 amendments to the By-Laws abolished the elected Vice-President and the requirement which provided that he be a member of the Board of Trustees and called for one or more appointed Vice-Presidents. Further amendment, January 25, 1956 provided that the Board of Trustees elect one or more Vice-Presidents to discharge such functions as may be assigned to them by the President or by resolution duly accepted at any meeting.

Between 1955 and 1959 Frank Lappin Horsfall, Jr. held the position of Vice-President for Clinical Studies; between 1955 and 1964 Douglas Whitaker served as Vice-President for Administration (between 1961-64 changed to Vice-President for Academic Administration). In 1964/65 Maclyn McCarty was elected Vice-President with special responsibilities in the clinical sciences. He is at the same time, Physician-in-Chief. In 1965 Carl Pfaffmann was elected Vice-President and Professor to develop a program of research and graduate instruction in the behavioral and social sciences. In 1969/70 a third Vice-President was added. This position carries with it the role of Secretary to the Board of Trustees and was filled by Charles Eugene Sunderlin.
In 1972 the University trustees elected Rodney W. Nichols to a new post of Vice-President for Program planning. He had been the first Director of the Office of Program Planning and Development.

In 1973 Albert Gold was named Vice-President for Academic Resources. As Vice-President he also retains his responsibilities relating to Junior faculty (Director of Postdoctoral Affairs) with additional duties in connection with organization, operation and planning at the University.
In 1974, effective September 15, Maclyn McCarty retired as Physician-in-Chief of the Hospital, which post was then filled by Dr. Attalah Kappas.
June 30, 1976 Eugene Sunderlin retired as vice-president of the RU.

June 1978 Dr. Albert Gold resigned from the University and October 1978 Drs. McCarty and Pfaffmann having reached retirement age resigned their positions as Vice-President. Mr. Rodney Nichols was elected to a new position of executive Vice-President and Mr. David J. Lyons was elected to a new position as Vice-President and Controller with new managerial responsibilities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is, in the main, from his position as Director of the Hospital though it extends through the period of vice-presidency. It deals, primarily, with recommendations for appointments, research projects and plans for meetings.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Thomas Milton Rivers became Director of the Department of the Hospital upon the retirement of Rufus Cole in 1937 and was named the first Vice-President of the Institute under the reorganization of 1953.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Late in 1941 Dr. Rivers organized a research unit for the United States Navy at The Rockefeller Institute Hospital, for the treatment of Navy-personnel suffering from certain specified diseases which were to be studied and which fit into the research program of the Institute Hospital. The diseases included streptococcus infections, cirrhosis of the liver and hepatitis.

In October 1943 Dr. Rivers visited the South Pacific and plans were made to establish a Naval Medical Research Unit Laboratory on Guam, in order to study diseases of the area in preparation for health needs of the Navy.
